title: Exploring the Art of Solutions and Design - Innovating at the crossroads of Forestry, Remote Sensing, and Environment
text:
Your browser does not support the video tag. 


Welcome to my e-portfolio üëã
My name is Hieu (pronounce as ‚ÄúHeal‚Äù) Phung. You can call me Harry.
I am a fresh graduate student in Master of Geomatics for Environmental Management at The University of British Columbia.
Before coming to Canada, I have completed my Bachelor‚Äôs in Energy and Environmental Engineering at Tampere University of Applied Sciences in Finland. I also completed one Master‚Äôs programme in Environmental Engineering in Tampere University in Finland.
It is interesting that, after my first master‚Äôs graduation, I decided to revolve my career path to the field of GIS and Forestry because I recognized an interconnection between environment, forestry and remote sensing field.
In my e-portfolio, I hope to deliver insights, creativity and innovations to readers.
Thank you and enjoy your time exploring my space. Should you have any questions, please do not hesitate to send me an email.

Skills: ArcGIS Pro, QGIS, R coding, Python, ENVI, eCognition, Google Earth Engine, AutoCAD, AutoCAD Plant 3D


 Contact Me

title: Detecting Change of Aboveground Biomass using Landsat 9 and PlanetScope data
text:
ArcGIS Pro
Linear Regression Analysis
Create Map
Calculating Vegetation Indices
Handling Trajectory GEDI Dataset
Scientific Writing
Research


BackgroundObjectivesDatasetsReferences


Forests play a vital role in regulating the global carbon cycle, yet their aboveground biomass (AGB) remains difficult to estimate over large areas due to limitations of field-based measurements. Remote sensing offers a scalable solution, but the choice of satellite data remains challenging. This study addresses the challenge by evaluating satellite-based approaches to estimate AGB in Kwahu South, Ghana



Identifying the optimal approach for estimating AGB in Ghana
Evaluating the accuracy AGB estimation models derived from Landsat 9, PlanetSocpe, and 30-m PlanetScope with GEDI L4A serving as a reference data




Landsat 9 imagery (date of the images: 12/2022)
PlanetScope imagery (date of the images: 12/2022)
GEDI L4A data (date of the data: 09/2022 to 02/2023)
Digital Elevation Model (DEM)



Pan, Y., Birdsey, R. A., Fang, J., Houghton, R., Kauppi, P., Kurz, W. A., Phillips, O. L., Shvidenko, A., Lewis, S. L., Canadell, J. G., Ciais, P., Jackson, R. B., Pacala, S. W., McGuire, A. D., Piao, S., Rautiainen, A., Sitch, S., & Hayes, D. (2011). A Large and Persistent Carbon Sink in the World‚Äôs Forests. ResearchGate. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/51498031_A_Large_and_Persistent_Carbon_Sink_in_the_World‚Äôs_Forests
Tian, L., Wu, X., Tao, Y., Li, M., Qian, C., Liao, L., & Fu, W. (2023). Review of Remote Sensing-Based Methods for Forest Aboveground Biomass Estimation: Progress, Challenges, and Prospects. Forests, 14(6), Article 6. https://doi.org/10.3390/f14061086

title: Detecting Change of Aboveground Biomass using Landsat 9 and PlanetScope data
text:
Study area
The study area is located in Kwahu South District, Ghana
Total area: 795.76 km2
Main climate: wet semi equatorial
Forest zone: semi-deciduous

title: Detecting Change of Aboveground Biomass using Landsat 9 and PlanetScope data
text:
Method
The main approach for developing AGB estimation model in this project is as follow: - Generated a rescaled 30-m PlanetScope imagery

Calculated vegetation indices (NDVI, EVI, NDWI, MSAVI, and GCI) from Landsat 9, PlanetScope, and rescaled 30-m PlanetScope imagery
Computed the aspect from the DEM
Applying random forest algorithm for AGB estimation with input variables were spectral bands, vegetation indices, aspect, and DEM. GEDI L4A was used as groundtruth data for validating each model
Evaluated the accuracy of AGB estimation model derived from Landsat 9, PlanetScope, and rescaled 30-m PlanetScope

title: Detecting Change of Aboveground Biomass using Landsat 9 and PlanetScope data
text:
Results

Model‚Äôs accuracy

Landsat 9 modelPlanetScope modelRescaled 30-m PlanetScope model










Result derived from Image ¬© 2022 Planet Labs PBC





Result derived from Image ¬© 2022 Planet Labs PBC



Though Planet had finer spatial resolution, it still demonstrated a less accurate result compared to Landsat 9. Meanwhile, the rescaled Planet provided the best performance, suggesting that spatial resolution alone did not determine AGB estimation accuracy. One potential explanation for this result is the misalignment between Planet‚Äôs 3m resolution and GEDI‚Äôs 25m footprint.That explains when the PlanetScope was rescaled to 30m, it better matched the scale of GEDI‚Äôs footprint, improving alignment and reducing fine-scale noise.


AGB Distribution Map



This map presents a sample of AGB predictions generated using Landsat 9 imagery. Due to licensing restrictions associated with PlanetScope data, maps derived from Planet imagery cannot be shared in this e-portfolio. However, a key takeaway from the comparison is the difference in how AGB is represented, especially in urban areas in the western part of the study region. In the Landsat 9 map, urban zones are less clearly separated from surrounding biomass values. In contrast, the AGB model based on PlanetScope data offers a smoother and more refined spatial distribution, improving the distinction between built-up and vegetated areas. This highlights the potential advantage of rescaling high-resolution data to a coarser resolution to enhance the consistency of AGB estimates by reducing noise while preserving meaningful spatial patterns.

title: Detecting Change of Aboveground Biomass using Landsat 9 and PlanetScope data
text:
Conclusion
In conclusion, this study evaluated the accuracy of AGB estimation models derived from Landsat 9 and PlanetScope, with GEDI L4A serving as reference. From the results, the most optimal model was identified. The findings demonstrated that finer resolution alone does not guarantee improved model performance. This study also emphasized the importance of matching the spatial scale of input data with reference measurements to enhance the accuracy of biomass prediction.
Access to my StoryMap

title: Analysis of Burn Severity and Vegetation Recovery at Prouton Lake, BC
Analysis of Burn Severity and Vegetation Recovery at Prouton Lake, BC
text:
Post-fire vegetation recovery
The yearly NDVI composites from 2018 to 2021 illustrate the temporal pattern of vegetation recovery following the Prouton Lakes Fire. In 2018, NDVI values are relatively low across the burned area, particularly in the central and southern regions, indicating limited photosynthetic activity and sparse vegetation cover shortly after the fire. By 2019, there is a slight increase in NDVI in scattered patches, suggesting the early stages of regrowth. This trend continues in 2020 and becomes more apparent in 2021, where broader areas show higher NDVI values (greener shades), reflecting increasing vegetation density and health. The gradual shift toward green and yellow tones over the four years indicates a progressive recovery of plant cover, although full canopy regeneration has not yet been achieved. These spatial NDVI patterns align with typical successional trajectories seen after wildfire events, where initial colonization by herbaceous species is followed by slower woody vegetation growth.

title: Analysis of Burn Severity and Vegetation Recovery at Prouton Lake, BC
text:
R Coding
Time Series Analysis


BackgroundObjectivesData descriptionsReferences


Prouton Lakes is located in the Cariboo Chilcotin Region of British Columbia, Canada, east of Williams Lake (Kitchen et al., 2022). It is situated near the Alex Fraser Research Forest (AFRF), which serves as a research and education site for sustainable forest management (Kitchen et al., 2022).
Fire severity analysis is a crucial aspect of post-fire ecosystem assessment and management (Miller et al., 2023). It involves classifying burned areas into different severity classes based on the degree of ecological change caused by the fire (Miller et al., 2023).



Investigated the burn severity at Prouton Lake
Analysed the recovery of vegetation in the years after the fire (2018 -2021).




Landsat 8 Collection 2 Level 2



Mitchell, K. A., Peng, L., Daniels, L., & Carroll, A. (2022). Patterns of infestation by subcortical insects (Coleoptera: Buprestidae, Cerambycidae) after widespread wildfires in mature Douglas-fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii) forests. Forest Ecology and Management, 513(1), Article 120203. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.foreco.2022.120203
Miller, C. W., Harvey, B. J., Kane, V. R., Moskal, L. M., & Alvarado, E. (2023). Different approaches make comparing studies of burn severity challenging: A review of methods used to link remotely sensed data with the Composite Burn Index. International Journal of Wildland Fire. https://doi.org/10.1071/WF22050



Necessary R package for this analysis

library(terra)
library(sf)
library(readr)
library(stringr)
library(lubridate)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(bfast)

The RGB composites show the condition of Prouton Lake and surrounding forest before (July 2015) and after the fire event (July 2018). In the pre-fire image, dense and healthy vegetation is visible as dark green patches, indicating an intact forest canopy. By contrast, the post-fire image reveals extensive areas of white, light brown, and grey, suggesting widespread vegetation loss and exposed soil ‚Äî typical signs of high burn severity. The boundaries of the burn scar are clearly defined, with sharp contrasts between affected and unaffected areas. This transformation is especially evident around the central and northern parts of the scene. While RGB images give a visual sense of change, false-color composites or spectral indices such as NBR or NDVI would provide a more quantitative assessment of vegetation health and burn intensity.



False color image

title: Individual Trees Detecting using different methods
text:
Pre-processing the data
Load the necessary library

library(lidR)
library(terra)
library(tidyverse)
library(rgl)

Preparation of data for analysis
For this study, the LiDAR point cloud data, stored in .las files, had already been normalized. This pre-processing step simplifies subsequent analysis by adjusting the elevation values relative to the ground surface rather than absolute elevation.
Extract the specific plot. The coordinate of the plot is listed in the .csv files.

title: Individual Trees Detecting using different methods
section: Detect individual trees using a point cloud
text:
Detect individual trees using a point cloud
The individual tree detection (ITD) method developed by Li et al.¬†(2012) segments trees directly from LiDAR point cloud data without relying on intermediate raster products like canopy height models. This top-down, region-growing approach begins by identifying the highest point in the cloud, assumed to be a tree top, and sequentially classifies neighboring points based on 2D spatial distance, adaptive spacing thresholds, and tree shape characteristics. By leveraging the 3D structure of the forest, the algorithm effectively distinguishes individual trees even in complex, overlapping canopies.


Code
#segment trees using li2012 algorithm 
segmented_plot_1 <- segment_trees(Lab5_Plot_1, li2012(dt1 = 1.5, 
                                                      dt2 = 2, 
                                                      R = 2, 
                                                      Zu = 15, 
                                                      speed_up = 10, 
                                                      hmin = 2))


Figure 1. ITD using Li et al.¬†2012 method

title: Individual Trees Detecting using different methods
section: Detect individual trees using a CHM
text:
Detect individual trees using a CHM
Dalponte and Coomes (2016) developed a tree-centric approach for individual tree detection (ITD) using canopy height models (CHMs) derived from airborne laser scanning. Their method identifies individual tree crowns by detecting local maxima in the CHM, then applies a region-growing algorithm to delineate tree boundaries based on vertical height differences. Each delineated crown is used to extract tree height and crown area, from which stem diameter and aboveground biomass are estimated using species-specific allometric equations. Hyperspectral imagery aids in tree species classification, enabling more accurate wood density assignment. This CHM-based ITD framework enables high-resolution carbon density mapping, though it is limited in detecting small understory trees hidden beneath the canopy.
Figure 2. ITD using Dalponte and Coomes 2016 method


Code
# Using Dalponte and Coomes 2016 algorithm to detect individual trees
tree_crowns_plot1 <- segment_trees(Lab5_Plot_1, dalponte2016(chm_plot1, 
                                                             tree_tops,
                                                             th_tree = 2,
                                                             th_seed = 0.45,
                                                             th_cr = 0.55,
                                                             max_cr = 10,
                                                             ID = "treeID"))

title: Analysis of Suitable Sanctuaries for Humpback Whales
text:
ArcGIS Pro
Suitability Analysis
Handling Vector Data


BackgroundObjectivesData descriptionsReferences


Hawaii is an archipelago located in the central Pacific Ocean, approximately 3850 km from Californa, USA (World Atlas, n.d). Aside being a wonderful place for visitors, Hawaii archipelago is also home to Humpback Whales during the winter time. The whales swim from Alaska to Hawaii to mate, give birth, and nurture their calves (Hawaii Wildlife Fund, n.d). Recognized as one of the world‚Äôs most vital humpback whale habitats, the Hawaiian Islands Humpback Whale National Marine Sanctuary was established in 1992 to safeguard humpback whales (Megaptera novaeangliae) and their habitat in Hawai‚Äòi (Division of Aquatic Resources, n.d). However, there have been reports about collisions between whales and human activities and objects such as cruise ships, whale watching boats, and fishing boats. Therefore, government agencies are working to identify the most suitable and expansive areas to incorporate into the sanctuary.
In order to complete the tasks, suitability analysis and overlay analysis were performed. Suitability analysis is a process used to determine the suitability of an area for a particular use or purpose based on given weighted criteria (ESRI a, n.d). Overlay analysis is a common method used in suitability analysis, which combines multiple dataset to create a comprehensive assessment (ArcMap, n,d).



The main objectives of this task is to create areas of the 5 most suitable sanctuary for Humpback Whales in Hawaii based on the weighted suitability index.




The data is obtained from UBC-postgres database. The necessary dataset used in this task are whale species, regions in which the whales appear, human activities that affect the whales.



ArcMap. (n.d). Overlay analysis. https://desktop.arcgis.com/en/arcmap/latest/analyze/commonly-used-tools/overlay-analysis.htm
Division of Aquatic Resources. (n.d). Hawaiian Islands Humpback Whale National Marine Sanctuary (HIHWNMS). https://dlnr.hawaii.gov/dar/marine-managed-areas/hawaiian-islands-humpback-whale-national-marine-sanctuary-hihwnms/
ESRI. (n.d). Perform a suitability analysis. https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/latest/help/analysis/business-analyst/understanding-suitability-analysis.htm
Hawaii Wildlife Fund. (n.d). Humpback Whale. https://www.wildhawaii.org/wildlife/whales/
World Atlas. (n.d). Maps of Hawaii. https://www.worldatlas.com/maps/united-states/hawaii







The interactive map above shows the top 5 suitable sanctuary for the humpback whales. These areas were identified through a suitability analysis based on three key factors: area size, whale sighting frequency, and vessel traffic. The 5 km buffer zones around each sanctuary highlight potential areas of influence, while the most suitable areas within the sanctuaries are emphasized in red. This visualization helps inform decision-making for marine conservation and habitat protection.

Download Static Map:  Download

The RGB composites show the condition of Prouton Lake and surrounding forest before (July 2015) and after the fire event (July 2018). In the pre-fire image, dense and healthy vegetation is visible as dark green patches, indicating an intact forest canopy. By contrast, the post-fire image reveals extensive areas of white, light brown, and grey, suggesting widespread vegetation loss and exposed soil ‚Äî typical signs of high burn severity. False color image

title: Analysis of Burn Severity and Vegetation Recovery at Prouton Lake, BC
text:
NDVI time series
The NDVI time series illustrates notable vegetation dynamics across the Prouton Lakes Fire area between 2013 and 2021. From 2013 to 2016, there is a steady decline in average NDVI, reaching a pronounced low in 2016 ‚Äî likely corresponding with the year of the wildfire event. This sharp dip indicates a significant loss of live green vegetation, consistent with high burn severity. In 2017, NDVI rebounds sharply, suggesting early signs of post-fire vegetation recovery. However, the values remain lower than pre-fire levels and show moderate fluctuations in the following years. The gradual upward trend from 2019 to 2021 may reflect ongoing regrowth and ecological succession, although the NDVI has not yet returned to its original state observed before the fire.

title: Individual Trees Detecting using different methods
text:
R Coding
ITD using Point Cloud
ITD using CHM Derived Model
Handling LiDAR Data


BackgroundObjectivesData descriptionsReferences


The Malcolm Knapp Research Forest (MKRF) is a 5,157-hectare forest located in Maple Ridge, British Columbia, approximately 60 km from Vancouver (The University of British Columbia, n.d.). Established in 1949, it serves as a world-class environment for research and education in forestry and sciences (The University of British Columbia, n.d.).
Individual tree detection (ITD) is a crucial technique in forest inventory and management for subsequent estimation of tree species, height, diameter, crown size and location (Luo et al., n.d). In this task, I am doing ITD using point cloud method and canopy height model derived method. The methods used in this tasks are based on Li et al., 2012 and Dalponte & Coomes, 2016.



Applied point cloud method for individual tree detection (ITD) (Li et al., 2012)
Applied canopy height model derived method for individual tree detection (ITD) (Dalponte and Coomes, 2016)




LiDAR point cloud data



Dalponte, M., & Coomes, D. A. (2016). Tree-centric mapping of forest carbon density from airborne laser scanning and hyperspectral data. Methods in Ecology and Evolution, 7(10), 1236-1245.
Li, W., Guo, Q., Jakubowski, M. K., & Kelly, M. (2012). A new method for segmenting individual trees from the lidar point cloud. Photogrammetric Engineering & Remote Sensing, 78(1), 75-84.
Luo, Z., Zhang, Z., Li, W., Chen, Y., Wang, C., Nurunnabi, A., & Li, J. (n.d). Detection of individual trees in UAV LiDAR point clouds using a deep learning framework based on multi-channel representation. IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing, 59(7), 5769-5785.
The University of British Columbia. (n.d). Malcolm Knapp Reseach Forest. https://www.mkrf.forestry.ubc.ca/about/



Necessary pakages for this analysis


Code
library(lidR)
library(terra)
library(tidyverse)
library(rgl)

text:
ArcGIS Pro
Suitability Analysis
Handling Vector Data

The data is obtained from UBC-postgres database. The necessary dataset used in this task are whale species, regions in which the whales appear, human activities that affect the whales.

Division of Aquatic Resources. (n.d). Hawaiian Islands Humpback Whale National Marine Sanctuary (HIHWNMS). https://dlnr.hawaii.gov/dar/marine-managed-areas/hawaiian-islands-humpback-whale-national-marine-sanctuary-hihwnms/
ESRI. (n.d). Perform a suitability analysis. https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/latest/help/analysis/business-analyst/understanding-suitability-analysis.htm
Hawaii Wildlife Fund. (n.d). Humpback Whale. https://www.wildhawaii.org/wildlife/whales/
World Atlas. (n.d). Maps of Hawaii. https://www.worldatlas.com/maps/united-states/hawaii







The interactive map above shows the top 5 suitable sanctuary for the humpback whales. These areas were identified through a suitability analysis based on three key factors: area size, whale sighting frequency, and vessel traffic. The 5 km buffer zones around each sanctuary highlight potential areas of influence, while the most suitable areas within the sanctuaries are emphasized in red. This visualization helps inform decision-making for marine conservation and habitat protection.

title: Environmental Projects
text:
AutoCAD 3D
CO2 Captured using Molten Salt
Research
Scientific Writing
Experimental Design

CO2 capture via electrolysis in molten salt is one of the methods that draws attention of scientists and researchers due to its valuable product and sustainability. The basic idea of this method is to use molten salts, with the help from anode and cathode, to capture and convert CO2 to valuable carbon-products such as carbon nanofiber (CNF), carbon nano onions (CNO), or carbon nanotubes (CNT). (Wu et al.¬†2017) Nevertheless, this technology has drawback. Several research showed that there were heavy corrosions on the anode used in molten salt electrolysis (Wu et al., 2017; Tang et al., 2018). Besides, lithium carbonate, which is mainly used in molten salt electrolysis, is becoming scarce (Reuter 2022). Hence, new carbonate salt and a suitable anode material should be researched to cope with the issue of corrsion and scarcity of lithium carbonate.
The main aim of this thesis work is to find suitable and inexpensive materials for electrodes to hold off the corrosion during molten salt electrolysis process. In addition, a system for molten carbonate salt electrolysis is designed and constructed for testing the materials in a laboratory scale system. Furthermore, the growth of CNT is investigated by zinc coated iron electrode to see if iron can catalyze the formation of CNT.
This thesis work is part of Hydrogen and Carbon Value Chains in Green Electrification (HYGCEL) project, in which new value chains from the development of Power-to-X (P2X) market was identified, plus, a guidance for electricity and hydrogen-based infrastructure should be examined. The work is in work package 5 (WP5), which concentrates on techno-economy of solid carbon products. The project is a collaborative project between Tampere University and Lappeenranta-Lahti University of Technology.


In direct reduction of CO2 to carbon, CO2 is converted directly to elemental carbon on the cathode during electrolysis of molten salt via a three-step electrochemical-chemical-electrochemical CO2 reduction (Ijije et al., 2014)

1st step:
CO2 + 2e- <-> CO22- (1)
2nd step:
CO22- -> CO + O2- (2)
3rd step:
CO + 2e- -> C + 2 CO32- (3)
Overall reaction:
3 CO2 + 4e- -> C + 2 CO32- (4)




Figure 1. Illustration of the reduction of CO2 to carbon



The experimental system was designed for specific purposes. Several experiments were done to test the durability of anodes and formation of carbon products using different combination of carbonate salt. The anodes which were used in this thesis were nickel, tin dioxides (SnO2), and galvanized steel. The combination of salt used in this experiment were Li2CO3 and Na2CO3-K2CO3-CaCO3.




Figure 2Figure 3Figure 4Figure 5



Preliminary design for a part of experimental systems



SEM photo of carbon products when galvanized steel (cathode) and tin dioxide (anode) were used in Li2CO3



SEM photo of carbon products when nickel (cathode) and tin dioxide (anode) were used in CaCO3-Na2CO3-K2CO3



SEM photo of the surface of SnO2 for corrosion analysis






Ijije, H. V., Lawrence, R. C., Chen, G. Z. (2014a). Carbon electrodeposition in molten salts: electrode reaction and application. RSC advances. Vol. 4(67), pp.¬†35808 ‚Äì 35817.
Tang, D., Zheng, K., Yin, H., Mao, X., Sadoway, D. R., Wang, D. (2018). Electrochemical growth of a corrosion-resistant multi-layer scale to enable an oxygen-evolution inert anode in molten carbonate. Electrochimica acta. Vol. 279, pp.¬†250 ‚Äì 257
Wu, H., Li, Z., Ji, D., Liu, Y., Yi, G., Yuan, D., Wang, B., Zhang, Z. (2017). Effect of molten carbonate composition on the generation of carbon material. RSC advances. Vol. 7(14), pp.¬†8467 ‚Äì 8473

The main aim of this thesis work is to find suitable and inexpensive materials for electrodes to hold off the corrosion during molten salt electrolysis process. title: Effect of Graphene/Gold - nanoparticles composite on the photocatalytics activity of TiO2
text:
Titan dioxide (TiO2) is used in the enhanced oxidation method because of its ability in photocatalysis. It has shown its potential in the application of removal contaminant in the environment. However, the ability of disposing contaminant of TiO2 is efficient only under a specific wavelength. Therefore, two methods have been researched in order to increase the ability of TiO2 in photocatalysis under UV ray and visible light. The first one is to add metal nanoparticles to the surface of TiO2. The other one is to attach nanocarbon dots on TiO2. In this thesis work, Graphene and gold nanoparticles were chosen as a support for the photocatalysis of TiO2.
The aim of this thesis is to research about the effect of Graphene/gold nanoparticles on the photocatalysis of TiO2. In addition, the ratio of gold and graphene also affected to the ability of photocatalysis. Therefore, different samples with various ratios were made to determine a necessary sample with a specific ratio. The color indicator such as blue methylene or Rhodamin B was used as a proxy for pollutants, in order to examine the efficiency of the photocatalysis between graphene/gold nanoparticles and TiO2.
The thesis topic is belonged to Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology.


When the surface of TiO2 is illuminated by light with energy level similar or higher than the bandgap energy ŒîEbg, the electrons in the valence band are stimulated and moved to the conduction band (Thiruvenkatachari et al., 2006). As the electrons have moved to the conduction band, there are several holes in the valence band, and these holes are positive charge (h+). The electrons in the conduction band are now negative charge (e-). In the valence band, there is a formation of OH* radical due to the oxidation of h+ and the water in the environment. In conduction band, O2- is formed by the reduction of e- and oxygen.(Thiruvenkatachari et al., 2006)



link to image
The OH* radical is the main factor that helps disposing the organic compound and convert them into CO2 and H2O (Waring & Wells, ).



The experiment consisted of 4 steps:

Creating Graphene/Au by sonic vibration and ultra violet method
Creating sample of TiO2
Creating sample of Graphene - Au/TiO2
Evaluating the photocatalysis





Figure 2Figure 3Figure 4



SEM‚Äôs photo of Au attaches to Graphene



Change of concentration of MB using various ratio of Au/Graphene - TiO2



Color change of methylene blue after different time frame






Thiruvenkatachari, R., Vigneswaran, S., & Moon, I. L. (2006). A review on UV/TiO2 photocatalytic oxidation process. University of Technology. Sunchon National University, 1 ‚Äì 2
Waring, M. S., & Wells, J. R. (2015). Volatile organic compound conversion by ozone, hydroxyl radicals, and nitrate radicals in residential indoor air: Magnitudes and impacts of oxidant sources. Atmospheric Environment, 106, 382-391.

title: Water and Sewer Network Design
text:
Fluidit Water Software
Fluidit Sewer Software
AutoCAD
Water Distribution Network Design
Sewer Network Design

This section will show an example of how water and sewer network is designed. The study site is a town plan zone of Isokuusi in Vuores neighborhood of Tampere, Finland. The software used for designing the water and sewer network was Fluidit Water and Fluidit Sewer.

title: Water and Sewer Network Design
text:
Water Network
For water network, we used branch and loop system to design the network to ensure the cost efficiency and the quantity of water distribution to the customers. The loop system was used to make the distribution run smoothly even when there was a pipe burst. Branched system was used when there were customers at the border of the network or the demand was not too many in number. The water network was designed based on 4 scenarios.

Maximum unit headloss: should be 1-5 m/km in dimensioning scenario. Values between 8 and 10 are acceptable in extreme cases.
Minimum pressure: typically over 25 m
Pressure difference: the values should ideally be less than 5 mwc/d.¬†Values between 8 and 10 are acceptable.
Maximum velocity: the values should be below 0.5 m/s. Values << 0.1 m/s might lead to water quality problem as the water might get stale.


Maximum unit headlossMinimum pressurePressure differenceMaximum velocity















For the scope of this project, the cost for installing the main pipeline was calculated. The calculation was done by Fluidit software. The map below shows the cost for each segment of pipe.



Example profile of water



From the water profile:

Most pipes have velocities ‚â§ 0.8 m/s, which is acceptable for urban networks.
Consider increasing pipe sizes in High Head Loss Areas

title: Water and Sewer Network Design
text:
Sewer Network
For the sewer network, capcity and velocity are factors that need to be evaluated carefully. The capacity values should be below 1 so that the system can be gravitational conveyed to the outfall. The velocity should be in range of 0.1 - 1 m/s to ensure the self-cleaning for the pipe. If there are self-cleaning problems, the diameter of the pipe will be decreased to increase the pressure => the velocity will be increased naturally. The manholes depth should also be in the range of 1-5 m.



The model shows neither capacity problem nor self-cleaning problem. There is not any manholes that are too full.



From the sewer profile:

The capacity (max) values are below 1, thus, the system can be gravitational conveyed to the outfall.
The velocity (max) are also in range of 0.1-1 m/s, which is in typical range of velocity in sewer system for self-cleaning purpose.

title: Water and Sewer Network Design
section: Final layout of water and sewer network
text:
Final layout of water and sewer network

title: Effect of Graphene/Gold - nanoparticles composite on the photocatalytics activity of TiO2
text:
Applied Skills

Laboratory Skills
Research
Scientific Writing

Titan dioxide (TiO2) is used in the enhanced oxidation method because of its ability in photocatalysis. It has shown its potential in the application of removal contaminant in the environment. However, the ability of disposing contaminant of TiO2 is efficient only under a specific wavelength. Therefore, two methods have been researched in order to increase the ability of TiO2 in photocatalysis under UV ray and visible light. The first one is to add metal nanoparticles to the surface of TiO2. The other one is to attach nanocarbon dots on TiO2. In this thesis work, Graphene and gold nanoparticles were chosen as a support for the photocatalysis of TiO2.
The aim of this thesis is to research about the effect of Graphene/gold nanoparticles on the photocatalysis of TiO2. In addition, the ratio of gold and graphene also affected to the ability of photocatalysis. Therefore, different samples with various ratios were made to determine a necessary sample with a specific ratio. The color indicator such as blue methylene or Rhodamin B was used as a proxy for pollutants, in order to examine the efficiency of the photocatalysis between graphene/gold nanoparticles and TiO2.
The thesis topic is belonged to Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology.

Mechanism of photocatalysis
When the surface of TiO2 is illuminated by light with energy level similar or higher than the bandgap energy ŒîEbg, the electrons in the valence band are stimulated and moved to the conduction band (Thiruvenkatachari et al., 2006). As the electrons have moved to the conduction band, there are several holes in the valence band, and these holes are positive charge (h+). The electrons in the conduction band are now negative charge (e-). In the valence band, there is a formation of OH* radical due to the oxidation of h+ and the water in the environment. In conduction band, O2- is formed by the reduction of e- and oxygen.(Thiruvenkatachari et al., 2006)



link to image
The OH* radical is the main factor that helps disposing the organic compound and convert them into CO2 and H2O (Waring & Wells, ).


Methods
The experiment consisted of 4 steps:

Creating Graphene/Au by sonic vibration and ultra violet method
Creating sample of TiO2
Creating sample of Graphene - Au/TiO2
Evaluating the photocatalysis
